question_stem: Suppose that the following simple linear regression model has been fitted to the Taiwan real estate data from topic 05. The model is Y = β₀ + β₁ ln(X₁) + e, where X₁ corresponds to distance to the nearest MRT. Suppose that I am hunting for a new property, but I am not willing to spend more than 50,000 NT dollars per ping. What is the closest distance to an MRT that I can afford, according to the above model?
question_stem_html:
Suppose that the following simple linear regression model has been fitted to the Taiwan real estate data from topic 05:

Y=β0+β1ln(X1)+eY = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \ln(X_1) + e

where X₁ corresponds to distance to the nearest MRT.

Suppose that I am hunting for a new property, but I am not willing to spend more than 50,000 NT dollars per ping. What is the closest distance to an MRT that I can afford, according to the above model?

items.solution_html:
From the fitted model,

95.0169−8.9235ln(X)≤5095.0169 - 8.9235 \ln(X) \le 50

Solving gives:

X≥155.21X \ge 155.21

Thus, the closest affordable distance is approximately 155.21 m from the MRT.
